term: Welcome to Blaise Wallet. To begin, you can create a new private key or import one.
context: A paragraph that greets the user in the initial opening

term: In the next screen, you'll see your new private key. It is a password to access your funds. It is crucial that you back it up and never share it with anyone.
context: A paragraph that explains what users should do with their new private key

term: If you lose your device or uninstall Blaise Wallet, you'll need your private key to recover your funds.
context: A paragraph that gives a security disclaimer about what happens if the wallet is uninstalled

term: Below is your new wallet’s private key. It is crucial that you backup your private key and never store it as plaintext or a screenshot. We recommend writing it on a piece of paper and storing it offline.
context: A paragraph that explains what users should do with their new private key

term: Are you sure that you have backed up your new wallet’s private key?
context: A paragraph to confirm if the new private key is backed up

term:
Welcome to <colored>Blaise Wallet</colored>.
You can start by getting an account.
context: A paragraph to greet the user when a new wallet is created

term: There are 2 options for getting your first account:
context: The first paragraph of the explanation for the process of getting an account

term: 1- You can get a free account using your phone number. <colored>Only 1 account per phone number is allowed.</colored>
context: The second paragraph of the explanation for the process of getting an account

term: 2- You can buy as many accounts as you want for <colored>%1 Pascal (%2).</colored>
context: The third paragraph of the explanation for the process of getting an account
A paragraph that tells users to enter their phone number to the text field below

term: We have sent you a confirmation code, please enter it below.
context: A paragraph that tells users to enter the confirmation code to the text field below
Users may see this after starting the account purchase process

term:
To buy an account, first you’ll need to borrow one for free. If you send at least <colored>%1 Pascal (%2)</colored> to the account within <colored>%3 days</colored>, the account will be yours and <colored>%1 Pascal</colored> will be deducted from your balance automatically.
Otherwise, it’ll return back to us at the end of <colored>%3 days</colored> and won’t belong to your wallet anymore.
It is recommended you only send a small amount of coins until you own the account.
context: A paragraph that explains the process of borrowing & buying an account
A paragraph that tells the user to enter their private key to the text field below

term: This looks like an encrypted private key, please enter the password to decrypt and import it.
context: A paragraph that tells the user that the key looks like an encrypted one and it needs to be decrypted to import

term: Enter an address to use a different Pascal daemon for RPC requests.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to enter a new daemon address below
A paragraph that tells the user that the URL is changed to the entered URL

term: You have 2 options for backing up your private key:
context: The first paragraph of the explanation for the process of backing up the private key

term: 1- Encrypted, which means it is protected by a password.
context: The second paragraph of the explanation for the process of backing up the private key

term: 2- Unencrypted, which means it is raw and not protected by a password.
context: The third paragraph of the explanation for the process of backing up the private key

term: We recommend storing the unencrypted version offline, by writing it on a piece of paper. You can store the encrypted version on a password manager for your convenience.
context: The fourth paragraph of the explanation for the process of backing up the private key

term: Create a new password to encrypt your private key.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to create a new password to encrypt their key

term: Below is your encrypted private key. It is protected by a password. You can store it safely on a password manager for your convenience.
context: A paragraph that explains how an encrypted private key can be backed up

term: Since it is encrypted with your password, if you lose or forget your password, you won't be able to decrypt it and access your funds.
context: A paragraph that gives a disclaimer about what would happen in case the password that was used to encrypt the private key is lost or forgotten

term: Below is your unencrypted private key. <colored>It is not protected by a password, which means it is crucial that you store it somewhere safe and offline.</colored> We recommend writing it on a piece of paper.
context: A paragraph that explains the process of backing up the unencrypted private key

term: Below is your public key. As the name suggests, it is intended to be shared publicly and prove that a particular operation belongs to your private key.
context: A paragraph that explains what a public key is

term:
This is a <colored>borrowed account</colored>.
If you send at least <colored>%1 Pascal</colored> to it in the next <colored>%2 days, %3 hours, and %4 minutes</colored>, it’ll be yours.
context: A paragraph that explains what a borrowed account is

term:
<colored>Your account has been purchased!</colored>
The transfer is currently processing. This process usually takes about <colored>15 minutes</colored>, in some cases it may take slightly longer.
context: A paragraph that explains that the account has been purchased and transfer is currently processing

term: <colored>Logging out will remove your private key and all Blaise related data from this device.</colored> If your private key is not backed up, you will never be able to access your funds again. If your private key is backed up, you have nothing to worry about.
context: The first part of the disclaimer that is shown when the user tries to log out.

term: Are you sure that you've backed up your private key? <colored>As long as you've backed up your private key, you have nothing to worry about.</colored>
context: The second part of the disclaimer that is shown when the user tries to log out.

term: Confirm the transaction details to send.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to confirm the info below to send
A paragraph that informs the user that the transaction has been sent succesfully

term: Enter a name below to change your account's name.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to enter a new account name below

term: Confirm your new account name to proceed.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to confirm the new account name

term: Your account name has been changed successfully.
context: A paragraph that informs the user that the account name has been changed successfully

term: Enter a public key below to transfer the ownership of this account to it.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to enter a public key to the text field below to transfer the ownership of the account

term: Confirm the public key below to transfer the ownership of this account to it.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to confirm the public key below to proceed with the transfer

term: Your account has been transferred successfully to the public key below.
context: A paragraph that informs the user that the account transfer has been completed successfully

term: Enter a price and an account that will be receiving the payment to list this account for sale.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to enter a price and a receiver account to list the account for sale

term: Confirm the price and the account that will be receiving the payment.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to confirm the price and the receiver account

term: Your account has been successfully listed for sale. We’ll let you know if someone buys it.
context: A paragraph that informs the user that the account has been listed for sale successfully

term: Enter a price, a receiving account, and a public key below to create a private sale for this account.
context: A paragraph that tells the user to enter a price, a receiver account, and a public key to create a private sale for the account
A paragraph that tells the user to confirm the information below.

term: The private sale has been created successfully. We’ll let you know if it is bought.
context: A paragraph that informs the user that the private sale has been created successfully

term: Confirm that you would like to delist this account from sale.
context: A paragraph that tells the users to confirm that they would like to delist the account from sale.

term: Your account has been successfully delisted from sale.
context: A paragraph that informs the user that the account has been delisted from sale successfully
A paragraph to indicate that the operation requires a fee

term: Please confirm the addition of %1 Pascal fee to this operation to continue.
context: A paragraph to tell the user to confirm the addition of a fee

term: This type of private key is not yet supported by Blaise. You may create a new private key and transfer your accounts to it using a different wallet.
context: A paragraph to tell the user that the private key type is not supported
A paragraph that tells the user to enter the PIN to unlock the wallet
A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to unlock the wallet
A paragraph to inform the user that there was too many failed unlock attempts

term: Authenticate to change account name to "%1"
context: A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to change the name of the account

term: Authenticate to delist the account from sale
context: A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to delist the account from sale

term: Authenticate to list account for sale
context: A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to list the account for sale
A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to create a private sale for the account
A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to transfer the ownership of the account
A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to send a specified amount of Pascal

term: Authenticate to back up private key
context: A paragraph that tells the user to authenticate to back up the private key
A paragraph that tells the user that the entered PIN is invalid
A paragraph that tells the user that the entered PINs do not match
A paragraph that tells the user to confirm the PIN
A paragraph that tells the user to enter the PIN
A paragraph that tells the user to create a PIN
A paragraph that tells the user that the contact has been added to contacts
A paragraph that tells the user that the contact has been removed from contacts
A paragraph that tells the user that the contact removel process is failed
A paragraph to tell the user that a specific number of contacts was successfully imported

term: Check out Blaise! Simple, sleek & secure Pascal wallet for iOS and Android: https://blaisewallet.com
context: A paragraph that is shared when the user shares Blaise with others via the option in the settings
